block.p: Clinton Urged to Act To Stem Bosnia Corruption A General Accounting Office report concludes that pervasive crime and corruption are blocking the success of the Dayton peace accord in Bosnia, and says the Clinton administration should consider suspending aid until local authorities show a determination to fight such abuses.

Clinton Urged to Act To Stem Bosnia Corruption A General Accounting Office report concludes that pervasive crime and corruption are blocking the success of the Dayton peace accord in Bosnia, and says the Clinton administration should consider suspending aid until local authorities show a determination to fight such abuses.

Yugoslav Constitution Amended Parliament approved constitutional changes that would let President Slobodan Milosevic run for a new term next year and that diminish the influence of Montenegro, Serbia's small sister republic.
More Policing by Chechens President Vladimir V. Putin promised to reduce the use of Russian policemen in Chechnya and to turn over more law enforcement responsibilities to pro-Moscow Chechens.
Holocaust Settlement Measure The German Parliament approved legislation governing a $5 billion fund for Nazi-era slave workers and other victims of the Holocaust.

Apology in Okinawa Sex Case The top United States military official in Okinawa apologized for an incident in which a marine was accused of molesting a 14-year-old girl, although no charges had been filed. The United States was taking no chances that demonstrations against the marines would mar a Group of 8 meeting in Okinawa in two weeks.
Palestinian Fund to Close Yasir Arafat's government, responding to Western pressure, divulged details of its long-hidden investment portfolio and said it planned to dismantle the fund entirely.

Planning for an AIDS Vaccine Steps should be taken now to enable a vaccine against AIDS to be distributed widely in the third world whenever one becomes available, advocates urged at the 13th International AIDS Conference, in South Africa.

U.S. to Delay Execution To Allow Clemency Plea The Clinton administration is planning to postpone the first federal execution in nearly 40 years, scheduled for Aug. 5, because of a lack of clemency procedures and because of concerns about racial and geographic disparities in death penalty cases, officials said. Lawyers for the condemned inmate, Juan Raul Garza, who was convicted of three drug-related murders, said they would ask President Clinton to spare his life.
Starr Aide to Stand Trial Charles G. Bakaly III, the former spokesman for the independent counsel Kenneth W. Starr, has been charged with criminal contempt in an inquiry into news leaks.

Nations Named in Secrets Case Federal prosecutors named several countries that they said Wen Ho Lee, a scientist accused of mishandling nuclear weapons secrets at Los Alamos, might have been trying to aid, possibly to help his job prospects after learning he might be laid off.
Bradley to Appear With Gore Bill Bradley plans to appear with Vice President Al Gore next week to show support for the man who trounced him in the Democratic primaries, party officials said.
Mr. Gore, speaking to an audience of elderly people, drew a sharp contrast between his Medicare proposals and those of Gov. George W. Bush.

Plea Talks With Political Donor Prosecutors were pressing James T. Riady, a friend of President Clinton and a prominent Indonesian businessman whose Democratic campaign donations have drawn scrutiny, to accept a plea bargain.

Civil Rights Inquiry Sought Representative John Conyers Jr. asked Attorney General Janet Reno to investigate the death of a 32-year-old black man who was choked to death outside a Lord & Taylor store in Michigan last month during a scuffle with security guards trying to recover a $4 bracelet.
A Guarantee to Rail Passengers Amtrak said it would offer every dissatisfied customer a free repeat trip, even if the railroad was not at fault, as part of a campaign to build ridership and revenue.

City Now Said to Be Open To U.S. Monitor for Police The Giuliani administration is now willing to consider federal oversight of how the police handle brutality cases, officials said, though obstacles remain to a settlement that would avert a civil rights lawsuit brought by the federal government.

Subway Signal Inquiry The M.T.A. inspector general is investigating allegations that supervisors who oversee the subway's signal system failed to make hundreds of back-up inspections of the lights that direct trains throughout the city.
Giuliani's Reaction to Book Mayor Giuliani responded to a book that claims his relatives had ties to the Mafia by saying that his years of aggressively fighting organized crime spoke for themselves.

Findings in Kennedy Crash The plane crash that killed John F. Kennedy Jr., his wife, Carolyn Bessette Kennedy, left, and her sister, Lauren G. Bessette, was probably the result of Mr. Kennedy's becoming disoriented in the haze that obscured the horizon over the water near Martha's Vineyard on the night the plane went down last July, federal investigators concluded. Mr. Kennedy probably had less than one hour's experience flying his plane at night without an instructor, they said.
'In God We Trust' Encouraged The Colorado State Board of Education passed a resolution, 5 to 1, encouraging schools to display the national motto ''In God we trust.''
Big Sister Triumphs Venus Williams defeated Serena Williams, 6-2, 7-6 (3), to advance to the Wimbledon final tomorrow against Lindsay Davenport.
Soccer Championship's Host Germany was awarded the 2006 World Cup over South Africa.

Big Opening for 'Big Brother' The debut of ''Big Brother'' on CBS Wednesday pulled in 22.5 million viewers -- more than ABC and NBC combined between 9 and 10 p.m. and a higher first-episode rating than either ''Who Wants to Be a Millionaire'' or ''Survivor'' had.
Lottery Company Shake-Up Gtech Holdings said earnings would fall short of expectations and that as a result its two top executives, William Y. O'Connor and Stephen P. Nowick, had resigned.
Retail Spending Cools Sales in stores open for more than a year rose by only 2.6 percent in June, compared with June 1999.
Factory Orders Booming Factory orders in May recorded the largest gain in more than seven years, suggesting that any slowdown in consumer demand is having only a limited effect on manufacturers.
